text:
Not sure this should be posted here, but I just saw an odd:
``` Activating environment at `~/Projects/XXXX/Project.toml`
   Updating registry at `~/.julia/registries/General`
ERROR: LoadError: LoadError: expected package `ThreadingUtilities [8290d209]` to be registered```
while instantiating a project on a cluster. Not sure I will be able to reproduce, but thought I should ask around ti try and understand what this is due to?

elements.text: Not sure this should be posted here, but I just saw an odd:

Activating environment at `~/Projects/XXXX/Project.toml`
   Updating registry at `~/.julia/registries/General`
ERROR: LoadError: LoadError: expected package `ThreadingUtilities [8290d209]` to be registered
while instantiating a project on a cluster. Not sure I will be able to reproduce, but thought I should ask around ti try and understand what this is due to?

text: FWIW, I don't directly use ThreadingUtilities, I think it comes from the dependency "chain" (not sure how to call this): DiffEqBase -> RecursiveFactorization -> LoopVectorization -> ThreadingUtilities.

elements.text: FWIW, I don't directly use ThreadingUtilities, I think it comes from the dependency "chain" (not sure how to call this): DiffEqBase -> RecursiveFactorization -> LoopVectorization -> ThreadingUtilities.

text: Well, the problem has gone away! :shrug: :grin:

elements.text: Well, the problem has gone away!

text: This happens if you try to instantiate a project but have a too old registry that is missing one of the transitive dependencies. If that is the case, a `Pkg.Registry.update()` would solve the problem, or any other Pkg operation that causes that to happen.

elements.text: This happens if you try to instantiate a project but have a too old registry that is missing one of the transitive dependencies. If that is the case, a
Pkg.Registry.update()
would solve the problem, or any other Pkg operation that causes that to happen.

text: I thought `Pkg.instantiate()`  did that. Note the problem solved itself somehow, too.

elements.text: I thought
Pkg.instantiate()
did that. Note the problem solved itself somehow, too.

text: It doesn't, but it would be a good feature if it did try to update the registry itself in case it fails to find something.

elements.text: It doesn't, but it would be a good feature if it did try to update the registry itself in case it fails to find something.

text:
Mmm, so how did it solve it? I think the only `Pkg` functions used in my script are
```using Pkg
Pkg.activate(project_path)
Pkg.instantiate()
Pkg.status()```
And running it first did not work (the error posted above), and running it again somehow worked... Surely `status` and `activate` don't update the registry, do they?

text: Can't say but if you have a registry from git (rather than a package server) you can backdate it with `git reset --hard` if you want to experiment with the hypothesis.

elements.text: Can't say but if you have a registry from git (rather than a package server) you can backdate it with
git reset --hard
if you want to experiment with the hypothesis.
